nodes.bodyText: How about using an Optional here?
PR is still in development. Let me get back when I feel ready.
sure

@svendiedrichsen I had a look now. The return value is just used internally. I didn't feel that Optional would have improved the code. This might be because I am not a big fan personally or because Optional isn't used in our codebase generally. I don't feel starting here is the way to go. Not even sure I ever want to start using it but if this should be something broadly applied to the codebase. To go from having to expect null basically everywhere to there should not be null references and if that means you need an Optional then use one.

NB. Both methods are copied straight from DefaultMetadata so they follow the same logic. This is needed because the registry checks for illegal reuse comparing new and existing Metadata with equals. Not having it implemented fails the test and considers them not equal and therefore illegal for reuse. It is beyond me how this did not pop up earlier.
NB. getNames() is a view, whereas getMetadata() is computed collection, therefore the change.

It would probably be nicer to deprecate these rather than immediately ripping them out.
There's an obsolete attribute for the Param annotation which:

produce warnings when used in asadmin, are ignored, and are not included in the command usage.

The most minor of gripes - but Asynch triggers me 😆
I assume you're trying to mirror the class name in the TCK, but I can't help but read it as cinch rather than sink (closest homophones).

See comments on deprecating rather than removing.
We might want to leave this for now so that it can still be accessed via get/set commands if necessary.

Another reason for leaving this in is the potential for domain validation exceptions on an upgrade - ottomh I can't remember what happens if there's an attribute in the domain.xml which isn't mapped to a config class, but I have a feeling it might throw an error.
OK just did a quick check and no it doesn't throw an error if the domain.xml has unrecognised entries on startup.
I this good news, meaning I can just erase them?

The only thing that's stopping me from saying yes is "what happens when someone updates from 201 and they were using this to use a non-default executor".
It might be nice to check if it's been configured to use a non-default executor on startup and print a warning saying it's not used any more - cleanest way I can think of to do this would be to retain the attribute and read it using the get method rather than doing xml parsing
I kept the fields and added the obsolete = true.
NB. Makes sure multiple calls to the supplier function always result in the same config instance.

Only just noticed this since apparently it's already there in the CircuitBreakerState for some method names: SuccessFul shouldn't have a capital 'F'
o((>ω< ))o
Going to fix that.

Just some food for thought: do we want the timeout and core pool size to be configurable? Even as hidden parameters of the set command so the uninitiated don't use them.
Probably fine as is but just planting the seed of thought (and/or doubt) 🙂
I'll add one for the keep alive time (time before an idle worker is removed).
See note above - do we want to have some hidden configuration knobs we can turn if this rate isn't ideal?
Good idea, I add one.
